document_title: Bladder stones: Causes, signs, diagnosis and treatment
subsection_content:
Principles in treating bladder stones are: (4)
Removal of bladder stones; Treat the cause of bladder stones to avoid recurrence
Use medicine
Medications commonly used to treat bladder stones include:
Pain relievers and anti-inflammatories: Medicines help relieve pain and discomfort caused by stones; Urinary smooth muscle relaxants: Drugs that help widen the diameter of the bladder neck. From there, the stones can move out of the body easily.; Urine alkalinizing drugs: Drugs that help regulate urine pH, can be effective in dissolving uric acid stones.; Diuretics: Drugs that help increase urine flow; Antibiotics: treat urinary tract infections.
Surgery
Most symptomatic bladder stones require surgery. Surgical methods include:
Bladder lithotripsy: The patient is given spinal anesthesia or general anesthesia for a short period of time. Then the doctor performed an endoscopy of the urethra and bladder. The stones are visible on the screen and the stones are broken up with a laser or shock wave. Broken pieces of gravel are taken out with a basket. The surgery is safe, with very few complications. Patients may need to use antibiotics before surgery, which helps reduce the risk of infection.; Open surgery to remove stones: If the stone is too large (> 4cm), or the stone is hard and cannot be broken, the doctor may consider open surgery to remove the stone.
